Department Statement:
The School of Social and Family Dynamics is an academic unit within The College of Liberal Arts and Sciences, which is the largest college at ASU and is organized in a divisional structure comprised of humanities, natural sciences, and social sciences. The atmosphere is collegial, priorities are fluid, and demands for assistance come from many directions. Our school offers a variety of degree programs in Family and Human Development and Sociology. Our faculty are at the cutting edge of their fields and are devoted to finding solutions to today's most difficult and important problems. The work of the school, however, is not focused entirely on problems. We address the positive outcomes associated with development, families, and social institutions. Understanding individual, family, and social strengths and resilience is critical to promoting and improving well-being and health. For more information on the Child Development Lab within the Sanford School, please visit our website at https://thesanfordschool.asu.edu/cdl.

Job Description:
The Child Development Lab (CDL) within the Sanford School at ASU-Tempe is currently seeking qualified candidates for its Classroom Assistant I position. This role will involve interacting in a full-day child care and preschool classroom with children between the ages of two to five years. You will interact both in a classroom & on a playground under the supervision of a lead teacher.
ATTENTION: This position is an On-Campus Federal Work-Study (FWS) Community Service opportunity with the Child Development Laboratory and paid through the ASU FWS Program.
To take advantage of this opportunity, you must be eligible for FWS, which means you must have a completed FAFSA on file and be eligible for need-based funding.  
To see if you qualify for FWS, please review your financial aid package or contact the Student Employment Office/Financial Aid and Scholarship Services via EMAIL: SEO@ASU.EDU. Please include your ASU Student ID # and reference this REQ Number.  
For more information about FWS, please visit: http://students.asu.edu/employment.
Essential Duties:
The position involves interacting with children (toddlers through preschool age) enrolled in the ASU Child Development Laboratory program. 
The job includes supporting lead staff with curriculum, routines, care, and education.
Desired Qualifications:
This is a Federal Work Study only position.
In most cases, no previous child care experience is required, however, experience is preferred.
Students with some limited experience with young children are preferred.
Students enrolled in a child-related field of study are preferred. Ex: Child Development, Early Childhood Education, Child Psychology. 
Must have or obtain a current TB test, fingerprinting required, and 2 professional references.
Must be willing to attend all student training offered at the center each semester.
The center is open Monday-Friday, 7:00 am - 5:30 pm. Please include your available hours for May, June, & July 2025 in your Cover Letter.
Working Environment:
The employee is managed by the Child Development Manager and the supervising Lead Teacher.
The employee will work with preschool-aged children both indoors and outdoors.
This job requires various types of movement, and you will be moving around a lot. You will frequently have to stand, squat, sit on the floor, kneel, and sit in child-sized chairs.

Duties are of a routine and simple nature; entry level. Requires direct supervision with relatively specific instructions. Little or no training or experience is required.

Department Statement:
The Programming and Activities Board is established for the expressed purpose of providing students with the best experience possible by supporting the ASU community with a broad and diverse range of programs and activities to promote the themes of Sun Devil Spirit, Pride, and Tradition, developing leadership skills and upholding academic integrity within its staff and members.
Educational Outreach and Student Services (EOSS) is committed to enrolling all qualified students at Arizona State University and assisting them in their academic success. EOSS provides a broad range of services and support to students and prospective students ranging from outreach efforts with K-12 schools, orientation programs for new freshman, bridge programs to assist the transition to a university environment, and a wide variety of services, programs and activities for enrolled students. EOSS has direct responsibility for multiple departments across four campuses, some of which include the Dean of Students, University Housing, Health Services, Counseling Services, Disability Resources, the Memorial Union, Upward Bound and TRiO programs, Sun Devil Fitness, Student Government, Student Media, Career Services and others.

PAB is established for the expressed purpose of providing students with the best experience possible by supporting the ASU community with a broad and diverse range of programs and activities to promote the themes of Sun Devil Spirit, Pride, and Tradition, developing leadership skills, and upholding academic integrity within its Staff and members.

Welcome Week Events
Sets in the West
Gold Patrols
Large Events
Tailgates & Watch Parties

Hold eight (8) regular office hours per week in the office.
Attend all Staff retreats, Staff meetings, weekly check-in meetings, and training sessions.
Attend five (5) Programming and Activities Board events per semester, not including their own or University-wide events.
Attend all University-Wide Campus Events (including: Homecoming Lantern Walk, Homecoming Parade, and Devilpalooza) and at least one (1) Homecoming signature event on another campus in addition to your one (1) local signature event.
Assist with staff transitions from year to year.
Assume full responsibility, in conjunction with the President and other Vice Presidents, of strategic plans, carrying out the objectives on an annual basis, and organizing the formulation of future strategic plans.
Assume the duties, privileges, and responsibilities of the President in their temporary absence.
Succeed to the presidency in the case of a permanent or prolonged vacancy in that office in accordance with procedures outlined in the Programming and Activities Board Constitution.
Serve as a liaison between the Programming and Activities Board and the university administration.
Assist and give input to the President and other Vice Presidents regarding all personnel decisions for the organization.
Maintain positive and effective relations with all Staff members and supervise Staff members assigned to them by the President.
Serve as a voting member of the Directors, unless otherwise prescribed by the Constitution.

Job Description:

Graduate Peer Career Coaches (GPCCs) support the Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering Career Center. GPCCs assist students with career preparation through appointments, deliver career presentations and lead activities to diverse groups, and support career events to maximize students’ employment marketability and capitalize on the Fulton Difference experience.  GPCCs also support projects to improve services and help the office run efficiently.
The ideal candidate for this position is a graduate student in the Ira A. Fulton Schools of Engineering with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. They must be available to work 15–20 hours per week in the Tempe office during core business hours (Monday–Friday, 9 AM–5 PM), with occasional evening and weekend commitments based on scheduled events and activities. A minimum commitment of two semesters is required. Strong written and oral communication skills are essential for effectively engaging with a diverse population. Additionally, the candidate should demonstrate a willingness to learn, adapt to a dynamic work environment, and consistently report to work on time.
Interested students should apply online by submitting a current resume that highlights relevant skills and job-related experience related to their major. Additionally, applicants must provide a cover letter outlining their interest in the position, qualifications, and expected graduation date. The cover letter should also include their availability for the current semester between 9 AM and 5 PM, Monday through Friday, and, if applicable, confirm their ability to work in Tempe during the summer of 2025.
Essential Duties:
Hold in-person or virtual appointments with individuals or groups of students to provide guidance in career development related activities such as job search, resume/cover letters, online profiles and practice interviews. Formulate and ask insightful questions. Provide personalized constructive feedback including areas of success, areas for improvement and avenues to achieve success.
Deliver in-person and web-based presentations to instruct large groups of students on the use of career development tools and job search resources, resume/cover letter writing, online profiles, career fair strategies and interview techniques.
Promote, organize and assist with events such as career fairs, industry events, mixers, on campus interviews and workshops sponsored by the Engineering Career Center.  Will take shifts at career fairs and events as needed. May occasionally involve working evenings and weekends.
Serve as champions, or point of contact, for various career center operations such as marketing, social media, resume tools, on-line job-related software, and career website.
Communicate with students and employers via phone, email, in person and online.
Exhibit outstanding judgment in confidentiality, accuracy, and professionalism while handling sensitive student information.
Enter detailed appointment and event notes into various systems.
Lead projects as needed for the Career Center.
Assist with front desk activities as needed.
Must be at ease with learning new technologies and working in a fast-paced, dynamic environment.
Perform other duties as assigned
Training:
Continued training may take place on Saturdays if there are no weekday times when all coaches are available. 
Desired Qualifications:
Two years of job-related work experience related to your major.
Computer Science, Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering or related majors.
Available to work in the Tempe office during summer 2025.
Will graduate May 2026 or later.
Working Environment: 
Activities are performed in an environmentally controlled office/classroom setting subject to extended periods of sitting, keyboarding and manipulating a computer mouse (75%).  Frequently required to stand for varying lengths of time and travel moderate distances to perform work (25%).  Regular activities require the ability to quickly change priorities, which may include and/or are subject to resolution of conflicts.  Evidence of effective communication skills to perform essential functions.  Telephone, computer (monitor, keyboard and mouse), printer and copier.  
Minimum Qualifications:
Duties are technical and complex and involve a high degree of responsibility and judgment. May supervise or direct activities of other student employees. A significant amount of specialized training or experience is required.

Driving is not required for this position.

Department Statement:
The Herberger Institute comprises six schools: ASU FIDM; the School of Art; the School of Arts, Media and Engineering; The Design School; The Sidney Poitier New American Film School; and the School of Music, Dance and Theatre; and two museums: ASU Art Museum and the ASU FIDM Museum. With programs ranked top 20 and more than 125 degree and certificate options in art, dance, design, fashion, film, media arts and sciences, and more, plus a top university art museum, a leading immersive media facility, and national and international partnerships, the Herberger Institute is a powerhouse of art, culture and design and a model of inclusive excellence.
Our mission is to position designers, artists, scholars, and educators at the center of public life and prepare them to use their creative capacities to advance culture, build community, and imaginatively address today’s most pressing challenges.
The vision of the Herberger Institute is to advance the New American University by embedding designers, artists, and arts-based inquiry at its core and throughout the communities it serves locally, nationally, and internationally. With almost 9,000 students and more than 750 faculty members, the Herberger Institute is committed to redefining the 21st-century design and arts school.
As part of Arizona State University, the most innovative university in the nation, the Herberger Institute seeks to drive and scale new ways for arts and design to have an impact in our world. We invite you to join our work.

Arts & Design Success Peers (SPs) work intentionally to foster connections among off-campus first-year students, transfer students, online students, and other arts/design students. Success Peers partner to build innovative and interdisciplinary communities across the entire arts corridor and within the greater ASU community. SPs are upper-division Herberger Institute Design and the Arts undergraduate students who act as inspirational guides and role models on how to live a fully integrated life in the arts. 
Success Peers coordinate engaging programs on digital platforms and in person. They coordinate social media and marketing to connect students to one another and promote events. They run HIVE - a hub for ASU creatives. They work with communities to foster creative and artistic development, and they advocate for the creative student voice. 
The Arts & Design Success Peer team consists of various student leaders supporting different areas such as visual and multimedia design, digital student engagement, student communication, events management, content creation, outreach coordination, fostering interdisciplinary collaboration, and more. This specific role will focus on creating engagement with online students in the Herberger Institute for Design & the Arts.

Comply with all ASU rules, regulations, and policies. 
Develop strategies for connecting students to one another.
Highlight student artists and their work.

Educational Outreach and Student Services (EOSS) is committed to enrolling all qualified students at Arizona State University and assisting them in their academic success. Job Description:
Salary: $14.85 per hour
Being a part of Sun Devil Fitness and Wellness as a Sports Programs Supervisor means uniquely engaging in our mission of building an ASU student community that embraces physical, mental, spiritual, and social well-being of self and others as a hallmark of the Sun Devil Experience. We do this through the Sun Devil Way, exemplifying; achievement, engagement and responsibility.
In the process you will also gain vital experiences that will help you live a healthier life and develop your professional portfolio by enhancing your communication, critical thinking and leadership skills. Our goal is to serve as a support that enriches your academic, personal and career success.
As an integral part of Sun Devil Fitness and Wellness, Sports Programs Supervisor are providing structured recreational opportunities to students on a nightly basis. We do this by promoting an atmosphere that is not only competitive, but supportive to the fitness needs of everyone in our student body. These opportunities support thriving in academics, a healthy lifestyle, and student engagement. 
As a Sports Programs Supervisor, you are responsible for the administration and execution of all scheduled Sports Programs activities at the assigned facility. The Supervisor is responsible for enforcing the policies and procedures of that facility and program. The Supervisor works with the nightly Manager to ensure participant and employee safety.
Essential Duties:
Serve as an official/referee/umpire for intramural contests
Facilitate drop-in and open activities.
Serve as a game monitor for non-officiated sports.
Aid in facilitating virtual activities.
Learn both the rules of the game and the mechanics necessary to enforce the rules.
Exercise authority in an impartial, firm and controlled manner.
Dress neatly and appropriately for each shift.
Be punctual and professional in the fulfillment of their responsibilities.
Supervise the set-up and take-down of sports sites and equipment, including but not limited to water, ice, first aid, and all other items for sports programs.
Follow emergency care procedures in the event of an injury or emergency through implementation of CPR and First-Aid.
Identify and report emergency situations quickly.
Accept constructive criticism as a means to improvement.
Diffuse conflict with participants, does not escalate conflict.
Effectively communicate with Sports Programs Manager regarding participant and facility issues.
Perform other duties as specified by the Program Manager, Student Coordinator, or Professional Staff
Desired Qualifications:
Current ASU student enrolled in at least one credit hour.
Before starting - Attain and maintain all ASU SDFC training required: American Red Cross CPR for the Professional Rescuer/AED and Standard First Aid certifications (offered through Sun Devil Fitness once employed) in order to be hired.
A sports background is helpful, but not required.
Ability to work in a teamwork-oriented environment.
Must be observant, safety conscious and able to react calmly and quickly in case of an emergency.
Ability to communicate effectively, possesses mature judgment and sound decision-making
Ability to motivate participants in the areas of wellbeing and teamwork. 
Ability to guide session activities that meet individual needs for each participant.
Ability to effectively apply methods when constructive feedback is given.
Working Environment:
Work in a fast-paced environment.
Sit or stand for prolonged periods of time.
Ability to lift 35 lbs.
Work nights and weekends
Minimum Qualifications:
Duties are varied and less routine and involve a moderate degree of responsibility and judgment. May lead or coordinate activities of other student employees. Requires previous knowledge or skill and/or equivalent experience or training.

Driving is not required for this position.
